awd_titl_txt: CPS: Breakthrough: A Dynamic Optimization Framework for Connected Automated Vehicles in Urban Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Connected Automated Vehicles (CAVs), often referred to as "self-driving cars", will have a profound impact not only on transportation systems, but also in terms of associated economic, environmental, and social effects. As with any such major transformative undertaking, quantifying the magnitude of its expected impact is essential. The first part of this project aims at precisely this quantification (also referred to as the "price of anarchy") by assessing the difference between the performance of a transportation system as it now stands and the performance achievable in a CAV-based environment. A well-designed CAV-based transportation network has the benefit of expanding limited roadway capacity without affecting the existing infrastructure, but rather by seeking novel ways which focus on the vehicles and not the roads. A major part of the proposed project will focus on meeting this goal at the weakest links of a transportation system: the bottleneck points defined by intersections and merging points. 

The project will use inverse optimization techniques applied to large traffic datasets (from the Eastern Massachusetts road network) to infer unobservable factors, such as user behavior, and use them to construct a predictive model of traffic equilibria. Based on these new traffic demand models, forward optimization problems will be solved which will lead to socially optimal traffic flow equilibria achievable through a CAV-based system. A dynamic optimization framework will also be developed for urban intersections where the motion of CAVs will be controlled based on real-time data communicated over a wireless network to operate both safely and efficiently in a highly dynamic and uncertain environment. Towards this goal, the broader technical challenge of solving dynamic optimization problems on line will be addressed through novel ways that exploit event-driven methodologies with wide applicability in Cyber-Physical Systems. The overall framework will be demonstrated by implementing the key concepts and explicit control and optimization mechanisms in a miniature city test bed with an urban landscape and small mobile robots emulating CAVs with the ability to communicate and share data

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project has been to study the impact of Connected Automated Vehicles (CAVs) on transportation systems, including associated economic, environmental, and social effects. A network of interacting CAVs is a Cyber-Physical System (CPS), that is, a system that combines the physical dynamics of vehicles with the cyber components provided by the wireless communication layer that enables CAVs to exchange state information. The first outcome of the project has been a rational quantification of the best performance achievable by a transportation system consisting of CAVs relative to the current state of the art. Using actual traffic data from the Boston area road network, we have shown that the use of CAVs can automate routing selection and achieve a social optimum that can drastically reduce congestion. Using the same data, we also created a platform called CongestionMaps, located at https://salomonw.github.io/congestionmaps/DynamicPage/AM/index.html, where the entire Eastern Massachusetts traffic network is visualized and shows how traffic metrics have changed over a 3-year period of available data.

To assess the potential congestion reduction benefits from more coordinated route choices that CAVs could provide, the project developed new theory and methods to estimate from data the so-called Price-of-Anarchy (PoA) in transportation networks, which is a metric that quantifies the effect of selfish route selections by drivers on overall latency as a fraction of the latency that could have been achieved by socially optimal choices. Algorithms were derived to make socially optimal route choices by CAVs in a distributed manner, without significant coordination overhead. 

The project next sought to develop a control and dynamic optimization framework that can achieve the high performance based on the use of CAVs. For vehicles merging or crossing signal-free intersections, a fully functional decentralized optimal controller was developed so that the use of CAVs can achieve improvements of 30-40% in both throughput and energy consumption. This framework was subsequently  generalized to include multiple lanes with controllable lane changing and safety constraints that apply to merging points (rather than merging areas), thus allowing for less conservative but still safety gauaranteed controllers.

In order to provably guarantee safety in using CAVs, we have developed novel methods that deliver near-optimal performance (in terms of travel times and energy consumption) while ensuring that all safety requirements (collision avoidance, passenger comfort) are satisfied at all times in real-time vehicle motion control.

Our analysis of the energy consumption as a function of CAV penetration rates and of total traffic intensity at a typical intersection has led to the conclusion that approximately 10% of vehicles should be CAVs before energy consumption performance can exceed that achievable under traffic light control. However, this value critically depends on traffic flow rates (for example, in heavy traffic, a 90% CAV penetration rate may be needed to match energy performance under traffic light control.)

An interesting outcome of the project is a result showing that the presence of CAVs also benefits non-CAVs (human-driven vehicles). The intuition behind this unexpected result is that the presence of even a few "smart" vehicles improves the allocation of limited resources in a transportation network, hence allowing non-CAvs to benefit from this improved allocation.

The project's analysis has led to the conclusion that transportation networks can benefit from Mobility-on-Demand (MoD) Systems where demand is at least partially satisfied through vehicle sharing with multiple transportation modalities that also include private vehicles, public transport, and walking. We have developed methods that optimize the operation of MoDS through a combination of differentiated pricing and rebalancing, where the latter refers to directing or incentivizing drivers of empty vehicles to move to areas with excess demand.

The use of CAV using the controllers developed in this project will fundamentally transform transportation systems through increased safety, reduced congestion, and lower energy consumption and pollution, particularly benefiting urban environments.
